title: Henry Hall (Somerset cricketer)
text:
Henry George Hamlet Hall (24 December 1857 – 13 February 1934) played <a href="cricket">cricket</a> for <a href="Somerset%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Somerset</a> from 1879 to 1887; two of the matches he played for the team were <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class</a> games. He was born at <a href="Bedminster%2C%20Bristol">Bedminster</a>, <a href="Bristol">Bristol</a> and died at <a href="Southmead%2C%20Bristol">Southmead</a>, also in Bristol.
Hall, a lower-order batsman and a bowler whose bowling style is unknown, has the distinction of taking the first wicket ever taken by Somerset in an authenticated first-class match when he had <a href="Lancashire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Lancashire</a> opening batsman and captain <a href="A.%20N.%20Hornby">Albert Hornby</a> caught in the match at <a href="Old%20Trafford%20%28cricket%20ground%29">Old Trafford</a> on 8 June 1882, and he followed it with a catch to dismiss the second Lancashire batsman, <a href="Walter%20Robinson%20%28cricketer%29">Walter Robinson</a>. There were no other successes for Hall in this game: no more catches, wickets or runs when he batted and he then did not play against for Somerset in any first-class fixture for three years. By the time he reappeared for a single game in 1885 against <a href="Gloucestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Gloucestershire</a>, whose team included <a href="W.%20G.%20Grace">W. G. Grace</a>, he was being played as an opening batsman: to no great effect, as he scored 0 and 2 and Somerset lost very heavily. Though Hall went on to play minor matches for a further 10 years, this was his last first-class cricket game.
